newsitem.title: UK: London gold fixes uneasily at fresh 3-1/4 year low.
newsitem.headline: London gold fixes uneasily at fresh 3-1/4 year low.

text.p: Gold prics were hovering on fresh 3-1/4 year lows on Tuesday after weakening from London's intraday-high finish on Tuesday.
Dealers said selling in New York and the Far East was prompted by the continuing strong dollar and profit taking after Monday and Tuesday's short-covering rise.

Gold was fixed at $343.15 per ounce, down from $345.70 on Tuesday when it closed at $346.05/$346.55. The fix was the lowest since September 14, 1993 when it was set at $342.05. The previous low since then was on February 3 at $343.75.
"It looks as though it has further to go down although you would not like to put a figure on it," one dealer said.
Support from Hong Kong was muted given a softer tone and the pending Lunar New Year holidays. Business there largely featured selling gold in arbitrage deals against the strong U.S. dollar.
Dealers regarded the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) policy advisory group which begins its second and final day of debate on the domestic economy today as largely neutral.

A poll by Reuters of U.S. economists showed most of them did not expect a rise in the fed funds rate at the end of the meeting. But a majority of the sample forecast a 25-basis point rise on the fed fund rate of 5.25 percent some time this year.

The steady policy assumption was based on the absence of inflationary pressures but above-trend growth and some labour market tightness hinted at a possible rise later. More pressingly, the market was still uncomfortable about the possibility of further central bank selling.

"Whether it has happened or not, it is adding to the bearish tone," a dealer said referring to a spike in lease rates and heavy sale last Thursday which was immediately interpreted as the work of the central banks.
But support has come from physical buying described by market players variously as "very good" and "massive" and was particularly prominent in the Far East.
"The Tokyo premium is quietly positive over local London just now whereas a year ago it was negative," a dealer said.
The buying was seen as long term investment interest which would not come flooding back into the market for a 10 or 20 percent profit, dealers said.
The other metals also slipped off Tuesday's levels. Question marks over Russia's 1997 supply contracts of platinum and more importantly palladium to Japan were still supportive.
Platinum was down $2.25 at $349.50/$350.50 and palladium off $2.20 at $126.00/$127.00, both reflecting the sector's weakness. Silver was two cents down at $4.85/$4.87 amid sparse interest.
